standards.description: Identify algorithms in daily activities.
Optimize visual representations of algorithms.
Create algorithms that include step-by-step instructions to complete a daily task.
Describe how data is taken in (as input), stored, processed, and then produced as a result (as output) in a computational solution.
Model daily processes by creating and following algorithms that include sequence, events, and iteration to complete tasks.
Write the steps in algorithms that include sequence, events, iteration, and selection to complete a task or solve a problem, using everyday language.
Create visual representations for algorithms that include sequence, events, iteration, and selection to solve a problem or complete a task.
Create visual or textual representations of algorithms that include sequence, events, iteration, selection, and variables to solve a problem or complete a task.
Identify ways that technology might help others.
Design algorithms, using human-centered design principles such as empathy, user needs and requirements, and accessibility.
Design an improvement to a technology to solve a problem for someone else.
Discuss how human problems might be solved with the assistance of algorithms or programs.
Refine algorithms iteratively through user feedback to improve usability, accessibility, and user experience.
Design an algorithm or program that solves a problem for and meets the needs of someone else.
Modify an algorithm or program, based on feedback, to better meet the needs and requirements of others.
Develop an algorithm to solve a problem, using a process that considers the needs, requirements, and feedback of others.
Identify the individual parts that make up a whole object (e.g., a car has a body, windshield, doors, and wheels).
Demonstrate the correctness of algorithms for given inputs.
Verify whether an algorithm can or cannot help solve a problem.
Describe the function of individual parts within a whole object or system.
Hypothesize about internal processes and functions of opaque (black-box) systems to explain how outputs are produced.
Modify algorithms with repeating patterns to use iteration instead of repeated instructions.
Decompose a problem or task into smaller components to develop an algorithm.
Assess an algorithm's effectiveness in solving a problem.
Analyze algorithms for efficiency and accuracy, improving them with iteration and selection where appropriate.
Identify how algorithms might influence everyday activities and outcomes.
Describe common societal impacts, ethical issues, and biases of deterministic and probabilistic algorithms.
Identify how changes to algorithms might lead to different outcomes.
Modify an algorithm to address a specific societal impact, ethical issue, or bias.
Compare how different algorithms for solving the same problem may affect people differently.
Describe how algorithms might impact peers in varied situations.
Evaluate how different algorithms may affect outcomes, situations, and people with a wide range of needs.
Examine different perspectives, abilities, and points of view when designing algorithms and programs.
Choose the code that accurately matches an algorithm that includes sequence.
Create programs that include a sequence to complete a task.
Analyze how a segment of code works by identifying and describing the roles of key components (e.g., variables, conditionals, loops, functions).
Develop code from algorithms that include variables, data, and storage.
Compare how programming languages with differing syntaxes or semantics influence the coding process and problem-solving strategies.
Create code from an algorithm that includes sequence and events to express ideas or complete a task.
Create code from an algorithm that includes sequence, events, and iteration to express ideas or complete a task.
Develop code from a student-created algorithm that includes sequence, events, iteration, and selection to express ideas or complete a task.
Develop code from a student-created algorithm that includes sequence, events, iteration, and selection to express ideas or complete a task.
Develop code from student-created algorithms that include sequence, events, iteration, selection, and variables to express ideas, complete a task, or solve a problem.
Identify gestures and symbols (e.g., restroom signs, arrows for directions, thumbs up) in everyday life that represent information used to make binary choices.

Represent data, using appropriate data structures, including variables and collection types.MS-PRO-DH-05. Use appropriate data types (e.g., integers, text, Boolean) to store, update, and evaluate data within a program.MS-PRO-DH-06. Use iteration (e.g., loops) to access, update, and process elements in a collection.
Identify terms that refer to values that change over time in everyday life (e.g., today's date).
Label different representations of information (e.g., day of the week, line leader, your birthday) with a name and whether its value is constant or changes.
Identify the variables being stored and manipulated in a program.
Trace how data flows through and alters values in an existing program, using variables.
Use different types of variables to store, compare, and modify data, based on user input or program logic.
Modify existing programs that incorporate sequence, selection, and iteration.
Create modular programs that incorporate sequence, selection, and iteration.
Utilize reference documentation, online resources, and programming tools to assist in writing, debugging, and improving code.
Simulate program development roleplay to evaluate team decisions, considering potential harms such as data privacy, bias, or negative societal impacts.
Identify errors in programs that do not work as expected.

Use standard practices to test, debug, document, and peer-review code.MS-PRO-TR-12. Modify a program to improve usability and accessibility.MS-PRO-TR-13. Describe issues of accuracy and bias in computer-generated code.
Debug a program that includes sequence and events to correct errors.
Debug errors in programs that include sequence, events, and iteration.
Debug errors in iteration or selection in a program.E3-PRO-TR-04. Create alternative versions of a program to solve the same problem or complete the same task.
Debug errors in a program that includes sequence, events, iteration, and selection.E4-PRO-TR-04. Compare programs that complete a similar task and determine which would be easiest to repurpose.

Debug programs, using systematic strategies (e.g., testing while writing, tracing code) to ensure they run as intended.E5-PRO-TR-04. Create a unique program by modifying other programs or incorporating portions of other programs into one's own work to develop something new or add more advanced features.
Articulate how one has completed a task or solved a problem that takes multiple steps.EK-PRO-PM-06. Create a programming sequence to complete a task, working with a partner.
Explain the importance of attribution and intellectual property in programming.
Explain the function of a code segment.E1-PRO-PM-05. Collaborate with a partner to develop a program that expresses an idea or solves a problem.
Apply inclusive collaboration practices to support all stages of programming, from planning to testing.

Document the steps taken and choices made during program development, recognizing the contributions of others in the process.E2-PRO-PM-05. Use structured constructive feedback from a peer to improve a programming project.
Document a program, using comments, descriptive names, and structured guides, to improve readability, enable collaboration, and explain complex logic or code intent.
Articulate the function of a specific aspect of a program.E3-PRO-PM-06. Collaborate with a team to create a program, ensuring that all team members have a role and contribute equally.

Document a program, using embedded or external comments, to clarify its functions for others.E4-PRO-PM-06. Construct individual components of a program that are collaboratively assembled into a working project.

Create embedded or external documentation of a programming project, including explanations of code functionality, choices made, and attribution for the contributions of others.E5-PRO-PM-06. Collaborate with peers to design, implement, document, and review a programming project that expresses an idea or solves a problem.
Demonstrate how people create and collect various types of data to help answer questions.
Examine the relationship between data and metadata collected using computational tools.
Compare numeric and non-numeric data in terms of how they are collected and what they can tell us.

Evaluate the impact of precision and granularity in data collection and analysis, considering how different levels of detail affect accuracy, storage, and interpretation (e.g., rounding numerical values, image resolution, or sensor sampling rates).
Collect numeric and non-numeric data, using multiple methods, including observation, measurement, and survey.
Use computational tools such as spreadsheets to collect and organize quantitative and qualitative data.
Collaborate with peers to collect numeric and non-numeric data, following consistent procedures.
Create metadata that generally describes the purpose and contents of datasets, who collected the data, and how the data were collected.
Evaluate collected data for accuracy and completeness.
Organize data into tables where rows represent a "record" (e.g., a survey respondent) and columns represent attributes (e.g., case identifiers and the responses given by each person).
Collect different types of data, using computational tools (e.g., sensors, cameras, online surveys).
Use computational tools to organize, filter, group, and aggregate data (e.g., calculating frequencies, measures of center, and measures of spread).
Use computational tools to manipulate data (e.g., calculating new variables or attributes from existing ones).
Identify errors in data (e.g., missing values, incorrectly formatted dates) and ways to fix them.

Compare questions that can be answered with data investigations and questions that are answered through other means.EK-DAA-DI-03. Recognize patterns that people and machines can use to make decisions.
Pose data questions that anticipate variability in the data.MS-DAA-DI-09. Use computational tools to identify relationships among variables in a dataset and make classifications or predictions.

Investigate questions that can be answered by manually collecting data in students' everyday environments.E1-DAA-DI-03. Explore how patterns can be used by people and machines to make predictions and classify objects into categories.
Evaluate different representations of the same data for accuracy, clarity, and accessibility.E2-DAA-DI-03. Explain how computing technologies can learn from patterns in data.

Create data visualizations to demonstrate how different design choices can affect a data visualization's clarity, visual appeal, accessibility, and capacity to accurately communicate insights from data investigations.
Create a data visualization and a brief narrative to report the process and results of a data investigation.E3-DAA-DI-04. Explain how AI models can evolve when new data is added to the training set.

Evaluate the quality and limitations of a dataset for answering different data questions.MS-DAA-DI-12. Share the story of a data investigation with peers, including what data question was asked, how the data was collected and analyzed, and what evidence supports the conclusion.

Investigate a data question involving relationships between multiple attributes.E4-DAA-DI-03. Explore the relationship between the properties of training data (e.g., size, features, biases) and an AI model's output.

Analyze a dataset to identify the nature and possible sources of variability in the data.E5-DAA-DI-03. Use an AI learning platform to train an AI model to make decisions based on inputs from a dataset.
Explore how data can help a person make informed decisions in everyday life.
Explain the benefits and risks of allowing personal data to be collected and incorporated into datasets.
Investigate a variety of data questions that address the needs of a person or community (e.g., classroom, family, school).
Analyze how decisions made during data collection, data processing, data analysis, and data presentation can lead to biased data, misleading conclusions, and compromised AI models.
Distinguish among data collection approaches that may lead to poor information.
Analyze the societal impacts of data-driven algorithms and computational systems, including AI.
Design a data collection approach that addresses the needs of people from different backgrounds or groups.
Analyze privacy concerns related to collected data.
Analyze the benefits and risks of using data in real-world scenarios, including AI.
Examine the use of tools (e.g., tablets, robots, rulers, pencils/erasers, tweezers, magnifying glasses, mobile devices, apps) to accomplish tasks and/or solve problems.
Describe the structure and organization of file systems, including file naming conventions, directories, and file permissions, and their role in storing and managing data.
Describe the purposes of basic hardware components (e.g., display, system unit, keyboard and other peripherals) in a computing system, using accurate terminology.
Differentiate between web-based applications and local software, based on user needs, systems requirements, and potential societal, environmental, and ethical impacts.
Justify the use of software and its functions to accomplish tasks and/or solve problems.
Apply basic troubleshooting processes to identify and fix common hardware and software issues.
Explain how the basic hardware and software components of a computing system work together to perform input/output (I/O) operations.
Describe the use of sensors in your environment (e.g., motion sensor doors, classroom lights).
Articulate steps to implement common solutions (e.g., turn off/on, plug in) for hardware and software issues (e.g., lack of sound, will not turn on), using accurate terminology.
Analyze the basic components, advantages, and disadvantages of wired and wireless local area networks (LANs).
Explain the key components of the Internet, their roles and functionality, and how they contribute to its resilience.
Explain how computing devices connect to the Internet using wires (e.g., Ethernet) or wireless signals (e.g., Wi-Fi).
Model how information travels securely across digital networks through the use of physical and software tools.
Illustrate how people access the global network of the Internet to access information and communicate with each other.
Model how information in a network is broken down into packets (smaller pieces), transmitted between devices, and reassembled.
Apply practices for keeping personal data secure.
Classify common types of cyberattacks, including social engineering and malware.
Evaluate how sharing information online might reveal personally identifiable information (PII) and other details to people other than the intended recipients.
Evaluate the vulnerabilities of computing systems and data centers—the physical vulnerabilities (e.g., natural disasters) and intentional bad actors (e.g., data breaches, theft, dark patterns).
Explain processes for maintaining secure personal and private information.
Compare and contrast different types of cybersecurity and physical security measures and the trade-offs for users, data, and devices.
Evaluate how authentication, different levels of access, and security measures help protect information on personal and public devices and networks.
Describe Defense in Depth strategies and what steps to take in response to cybersecurity incidents in simple networks.
Model different methods of encryption and decryption for keeping information secure.
Justify the importance of monitoring and updating security measures to prevent unauthorized access to information and other harms.
Categorize computing tools based on what tasks they accomplish and how they might benefit the user.

Examine differences in access to computing systems, based on personal and social factors, including physical ability, geographic location, socioeconomic status, and age.MS-SAS-IM-12. Explain how widely used computing systems have helped society solve problems while simultaneously creating new ones (e.g., cyberbullying, environmental impacts).
Describe the benefits and harms that arise from an individual's use of various computing tools.
Evaluate an individual's role in responsibly using computing tools.
Describe the benefits and harms of widely used computing platforms to an individual's life and human connections.
Analyze the impacts of widely used computing systems and networks on ecosystems and the environment.
Collaborate on an improved design for a computing system so it can be better used by people with different needs, abilities, and ways of thinking.
Identify computing technologies used in modern daily life that have changed significantly in the last 50 years.
Evaluate how challenges in different communities around the world have led to computing innovations.
Compare the roles of individuals, communities, organizations, and governments in advancing computing technologies.
Explore the contributions of people from different cultures, backgrounds, and time periods who helped shape computing technologies.
Analyze intended and unintended impacts of historical computing technologies on society and the environment.
Compare daily life before and after the implementation or adoption of a computing technology.
Research how computer scientists and their work have shaped your local community.
Describe how computing technologies evolve in response to societal needs and changes.
Examine how a computing innovation changed the way people lived, worked, or communicated over time.
Describe how computing technology, used in daily life, at home, and at school, can help people.
Evaluate how design decisions in emerging technologies influence user experiences differently across different communities.
Describe how technologies new to students create both benefits and harms in personal and family life.
Contrast the features, functionality, and characteristics of emerging technologies with technologies that came before.
Hypothesize ways that new or improved technologies can solve a problem.
Describe ways that emerging technologies have influenced the development of new solutions or transformed existing processes across society and the environment.
Evaluate how people make choices about the use of emerging technologies, based on their needs and the consequences.
Explain how emerging technologies create new solutions that depend on expertise from multiple fields.
Investigate intended and unintended consequences related to emerging technologies.
Analyze the limitations of existing technologies and how emerging technologies change the way people work, behave, and communicate.
Identify how people use digital devices in their daily work.
Analyze how professionals in different careers use computational thinking to solve real-world problems.
Describe how computing is used in a variety of industries and careers.
Examine how changes in technology can create new jobs or change how people work.
Discuss ways personal interests connect to computing in different industries and careers.
Investigate how professionals in computing careers address ethical dilemmas.
Explain how computing technologies and skills are used across different industries (e.g., healthcare, transportation, and entertainment).
Illustrate how technology-driven challenges require integrating computing knowledge and skills with expertise from diverse fields.
Examine how professionals across industries adopt new computing technologies and develop new expertise throughout their careers.
Investigate how professionals collaborate with computing technologies to solve problems creatively, accurately, and efficiently.

Identify the individual parts that make up a whole object (e.g., a car has a body, windshield, doors, and wheels).
Identify how algorithms might influence everyday activities and outcomes.

E5.description: Examine how a computing innovation changed the way people lived, worked, or communicated over time.
Analyze the limitations of existing technologies and how emerging technologies change the way people work, behave, and communicate.
Investigate how professionals collaborate with computing technologies to solve problems creatively, accurately, and efficiently.

MS.description: Evaluate how challenges in different communities around the world have led to computing innovations.
Compare the roles of individuals, communities, organizations, and governments in advancing computing technologies.
Analyze intended and unintended impacts of historical computing technologies on society and the environment.
Evaluate how design decisions in emerging technologies influence user experiences differently across different communities.
Contrast the features, functionality, and characteristics of emerging technologies with technologies that came before.
Describe ways that emerging technologies have influenced the development of new solutions or transformed existing processes across society and the environment.
Explain how emerging technologies create new solutions that depend on expertise from multiple fields.
Analyze how professionals in different careers use computational thinking to solve real-world problems.
Examine how changes in technology can create new jobs or change how people work.
Investigate how professionals in computing careers address ethical dilemmas.
Illustrate how technology-driven challenges require integrating computing knowledge and skills with expertise from diverse fields.

standards.description: Identify algorithms in daily activities.
Optimize visual representations of algorithms.
Create algorithms that include step-by-step instructions to complete a daily task.
Describe how data is taken in (as input), stored, processed, and then produced as a result (as output) in a computational solution.
Model daily processes by creating and following algorithms that include sequence, events, and iteration to complete tasks.
Write the steps in algorithms that include sequence, events, iteration, and selection to complete a task or solve a problem, using everyday language.
Create visual representations for algorithms that include sequence, events, iteration, and selection to solve a problem or complete a task.
Create visual or textual representations of algorithms that include sequence, events, iteration, selection, and variables to solve a problem or complete a task.
Identify ways that technology might help others.
Design algorithms, using human-centered design principles such as empathy, user needs and requirements, and accessibility.
Design an improvement to a technology to solve a problem for someone else.
Discuss how human problems might be solved with the assistance of algorithms or programs.
Refine algorithms iteratively through user feedback to improve usability, accessibility, and user experience.
Design an algorithm or program that solves a problem for and meets the needs of someone else.
Modify an algorithm or program, based on feedback, to better meet the needs and requirements of others.
Develop an algorithm to solve a problem, using a process that considers the needs, requirements, and feedback of others.
Identify the individual parts that make up a whole object (e.g., a car has a body, windshield, doors, and wheels).
Demonstrate the correctness of algorithms for given inputs.
Verify whether an algorithm can or cannot help solve a problem.
Describe the function of individual parts within a whole object or system.
Hypothesize about internal processes and functions of opaque (black-box) systems to explain how outputs are produced.
Modify algorithms with repeating patterns to use iteration instead of repeated instructions.
Decompose a problem or task into smaller components to develop an algorithm.
Assess an algorithm's effectiveness in solving a problem.
Analyze algorithms for efficiency and accuracy, improving them with iteration and selection where appropriate.
Identify how algorithms might influence everyday activities and outcomes.
Describe common societal impacts, ethical issues, and biases of deterministic and probabilistic algorithms.
Identify how changes to algorithms might lead to different outcomes.
Modify an algorithm to address a specific societal impact, ethical issue, or bias.
Compare how different algorithms for solving the same problem may affect people differently.
Describe how algorithms might impact peers in varied situations.
Evaluate how different algorithms may affect outcomes, situations, and people with a wide range of needs.
Examine different perspectives, abilities, and points of view when designing algorithms and programs.
Choose the code that accurately matches an algorithm that includes sequence.
Create programs that include a sequence to complete a task.
Analyze how a segment of code works by identifying and describing the roles of key components (e.g., variables, conditionals, loops, functions).
Develop code from algorithms that include variables, data, and storage.
Compare how programming languages with differing syntaxes or semantics influence the coding process and problem-solving strategies.
Create code from an algorithm that includes sequence and events to express ideas or complete a task.
Create code from an algorithm that includes sequence, events, and iteration to express ideas or complete a task.
Develop code from a student-created algorithm that includes sequence, events, iteration, and selection to express ideas or complete a task.
Develop code from a student-created algorithm that includes sequence, events, iteration, and selection to express ideas or complete a task.
Develop code from student-created algorithms that include sequence, events, iteration, selection, and variables to express ideas, complete a task, or solve a problem.
Identify gestures and symbols (e.g., restroom signs, arrows for directions, thumbs up) in everyday life that represent information used to make binary choices.

Represent data, using appropriate data structures, including variables and collection types.MS-PRO-DH-05. Use appropriate data types (e.g., integers, text, Boolean) to store, update, and evaluate data within a program.MS-PRO-DH-06. Use iteration (e.g., loops) to access, update, and process elements in a collection.
Identify terms that refer to values that change over time in everyday life (e.g., today's date).
Label different representations of information (e.g., day of the week, line leader, your birthday) with a name and whether its value is constant or changes.
Identify the variables being stored and manipulated in a program.
Trace how data flows through and alters values in an existing program, using variables.
Use different types of variables to store, compare, and modify data, based on user input or program logic.
Modify existing programs that incorporate sequence, selection, and iteration.
Create modular programs that incorporate sequence, selection, and iteration.
Utilize reference documentation, online resources, and programming tools to assist in writing, debugging, and improving code.
Simulate program development roleplay to evaluate team decisions, considering potential harms such as data privacy, bias, or negative societal impacts.
Identify errors in programs that do not work as expected.

Use standard practices to test, debug, document, and peer-review code.MS-PRO-TR-12. Modify a program to improve usability and accessibility.MS-PRO-TR-13. Describe issues of accuracy and bias in computer-generated code.
Debug a program that includes sequence and events to correct errors.
Debug errors in programs that include sequence, events, and iteration.
Debug errors in iteration or selection in a program.E3-PRO-TR-04. Create alternative versions of a program to solve the same problem or complete the same task.
Debug errors in a program that includes sequence, events, iteration, and selection.E4-PRO-TR-04. Compare programs that complete a similar task and determine which would be easiest to repurpose.

Debug programs, using systematic strategies (e.g., testing while writing, tracing code) to ensure they run as intended.E5-PRO-TR-04. Create a unique program by modifying other programs or incorporating portions of other programs into one's own work to develop something new or add more advanced features.
Articulate how one has completed a task or solved a problem that takes multiple steps.EK-PRO-PM-06. Create a programming sequence to complete a task, working with a partner.
Explain the importance of attribution and intellectual property in programming.
Explain the function of a code segment.E1-PRO-PM-05. Collaborate with a partner to develop a program that expresses an idea or solves a problem.
Apply inclusive collaboration practices to support all stages of programming, from planning to testing.

Document the steps taken and choices made during program development, recognizing the contributions of others in the process.E2-PRO-PM-05. Use structured constructive feedback from a peer to improve a programming project.
Document a program, using comments, descriptive names, and structured guides, to improve readability, enable collaboration, and explain complex logic or code intent.
Articulate the function of a specific aspect of a program.E3-PRO-PM-06. Collaborate with a team to create a program, ensuring that all team members have a role and contribute equally.

Document a program, using embedded or external comments, to clarify its functions for others.E4-PRO-PM-06. Construct individual components of a program that are collaboratively assembled into a working project.

Create embedded or external documentation of a programming project, including explanations of code functionality, choices made, and attribution for the contributions of others.E5-PRO-PM-06. Collaborate with peers to design, implement, document, and review a programming project that expresses an idea or solves a problem.
Demonstrate how people create and collect various types of data to help answer questions.
Examine the relationship between data and metadata collected using computational tools.
Compare numeric and non-numeric data in terms of how they are collected and what they can tell us.

Evaluate the impact of precision and granularity in data collection and analysis, considering how different levels of detail affect accuracy, storage, and interpretation (e.g., rounding numerical values, image resolution, or sensor sampling rates).
Collect numeric and non-numeric data, using multiple methods, including observation, measurement, and survey.
Use computational tools such as spreadsheets to collect and organize quantitative and qualitative data.
Collaborate with peers to collect numeric and non-numeric data, following consistent procedures.
Create metadata that generally describes the purpose and contents of datasets, who collected the data, and how the data were collected.
Evaluate collected data for accuracy and completeness.
Organize data into tables where rows represent a "record" (e.g., a survey respondent) and columns represent attributes (e.g., case identifiers and the responses given by each person).
Collect different types of data, using computational tools (e.g., sensors, cameras, online surveys).
Use computational tools to organize, filter, group, and aggregate data (e.g., calculating frequencies, measures of center, and measures of spread).
Use computational tools to manipulate data (e.g., calculating new variables or attributes from existing ones).
Identify errors in data (e.g., missing values, incorrectly formatted dates) and ways to fix them.

Compare questions that can be answered with data investigations and questions that are answered through other means.EK-DAA-DI-03. Recognize patterns that people and machines can use to make decisions.
Pose data questions that anticipate variability in the data.MS-DAA-DI-09. Use computational tools to identify relationships among variables in a dataset and make classifications or predictions.

Investigate questions that can be answered by manually collecting data in students' everyday environments.E1-DAA-DI-03. Explore how patterns can be used by people and machines to make predictions and classify objects into categories.
Evaluate different representations of the same data for accuracy, clarity, and accessibility.E2-DAA-DI-03. Explain how computing technologies can learn from patterns in data.

Create data visualizations to demonstrate how different design choices can affect a data visualization's clarity, visual appeal, accessibility, and capacity to accurately communicate insights from data investigations.
Create a data visualization and a brief narrative to report the process and results of a data investigation.E3-DAA-DI-04. Explain how AI models can evolve when new data is added to the training set.

Evaluate the quality and limitations of a dataset for answering different data questions.MS-DAA-DI-12. Share the story of a data investigation with peers, including what data question was asked, how the data was collected and analyzed, and what evidence supports the conclusion.

Investigate a data question involving relationships between multiple attributes.E4-DAA-DI-03. Explore the relationship between the properties of training data (e.g., size, features, biases) and an AI model's output.

Analyze a dataset to identify the nature and possible sources of variability in the data.E5-DAA-DI-03. Use an AI learning platform to train an AI model to make decisions based on inputs from a dataset.
Explore how data can help a person make informed decisions in everyday life.
Explain the benefits and risks of allowing personal data to be collected and incorporated into datasets.
Investigate a variety of data questions that address the needs of a person or community (e.g., classroom, family, school).
Analyze how decisions made during data collection, data processing, data analysis, and data presentation can lead to biased data, misleading conclusions, and compromised AI models.
Distinguish among data collection approaches that may lead to poor information.
Analyze the societal impacts of data-driven algorithms and computational systems, including AI.
Design a data collection approach that addresses the needs of people from different backgrounds or groups.
Analyze privacy concerns related to collected data.
Analyze the benefits and risks of using data in real-world scenarios, including AI.
Examine the use of tools (e.g., tablets, robots, rulers, pencils/erasers, tweezers, magnifying glasses, mobile devices, apps) to accomplish tasks and/or solve problems.
Describe the structure and organization of file systems, including file naming conventions, directories, and file permissions, and their role in storing and managing data.
Describe the purposes of basic hardware components (e.g., display, system unit, keyboard and other peripherals) in a computing system, using accurate terminology.
Differentiate between web-based applications and local software, based on user needs, systems requirements, and potential societal, environmental, and ethical impacts.
Justify the use of software and its functions to accomplish tasks and/or solve problems.
Apply basic troubleshooting processes to identify and fix common hardware and software issues.
Explain how the basic hardware and software components of a computing system work together to perform input/output (I/O) operations.
Describe the use of sensors in your environment (e.g., motion sensor doors, classroom lights).
Articulate steps to implement common solutions (e.g., turn off/on, plug in) for hardware and software issues (e.g., lack of sound, will not turn on), using accurate terminology.
Analyze the basic components, advantages, and disadvantages of wired and wireless local area networks (LANs).
Explain the key components of the Internet, their roles and functionality, and how they contribute to its resilience.
Explain how computing devices connect to the Internet using wires (e.g., Ethernet) or wireless signals (e.g., Wi-Fi).
Model how information travels securely across digital networks through the use of physical and software tools.
Illustrate how people access the global network of the Internet to access information and communicate with each other.
Model how information in a network is broken down into packets (smaller pieces), transmitted between devices, and reassembled.
Apply practices for keeping personal data secure.
Classify common types of cyberattacks, including social engineering and malware.
Evaluate how sharing information online might reveal personally identifiable information (PII) and other details to people other than the intended recipients.
Evaluate the vulnerabilities of computing systems and data centers—the physical vulnerabilities (e.g., natural disasters) and intentional bad actors (e.g., data breaches, theft, dark patterns).
Explain processes for maintaining secure personal and private information.
Compare and contrast different types of cybersecurity and physical security measures and the trade-offs for users, data, and devices.
Evaluate how authentication, different levels of access, and security measures help protect information on personal and public devices and networks.
Describe Defense in Depth strategies and what steps to take in response to cybersecurity incidents in simple networks.
Model different methods of encryption and decryption for keeping information secure.
Justify the importance of monitoring and updating security measures to prevent unauthorized access to information and other harms.
Categorize computing tools based on what tasks they accomplish and how they might benefit the user.

Examine differences in access to computing systems, based on personal and social factors, including physical ability, geographic location, socioeconomic status, and age.MS-SAS-IM-12. Explain how widely used computing systems have helped society solve problems while simultaneously creating new ones (e.g., cyberbullying, environmental impacts).
Describe the benefits and harms that arise from an individual's use of various computing tools.
Evaluate an individual's role in responsibly using computing tools.
Describe the benefits and harms of widely used computing platforms to an individual's life and human connections.
Analyze the impacts of widely used computing systems and networks on ecosystems and the environment.
Collaborate on an improved design for a computing system so it can be better used by people with different needs, abilities, and ways of thinking.
Identify computing technologies used in modern daily life that have changed significantly in the last 50 years.
Evaluate how challenges in different communities around the world have led to computing innovations.
Compare the roles of individuals, communities, organizations, and governments in advancing computing technologies.
Explore the contributions of people from different cultures, backgrounds, and time periods who helped shape computing technologies.
Analyze intended and unintended impacts of historical computing technologies on society and the environment.
Compare daily life before and after the implementation or adoption of a computing technology.
Research how computer scientists and their work have shaped your local community.
Describe how computing technologies evolve in response to societal needs and changes.
Examine how a computing innovation changed the way people lived, worked, or communicated over time.
Describe how computing technology, used in daily life, at home, and at school, can help people.
Evaluate how design decisions in emerging technologies influence user experiences differently across different communities.
Describe how technologies new to students create both benefits and harms in personal and family life.
Contrast the features, functionality, and characteristics of emerging technologies with technologies that came before.
Hypothesize ways that new or improved technologies can solve a problem.
Describe ways that emerging technologies have influenced the development of new solutions or transformed existing processes across society and the environment.
Evaluate how people make choices about the use of emerging technologies, based on their needs and the consequences.
Explain how emerging technologies create new solutions that depend on expertise from multiple fields.
Investigate intended and unintended consequences related to emerging technologies.
Analyze the limitations of existing technologies and how emerging technologies change the way people work, behave, and communicate.
Identify how people use digital devices in their daily work.
Analyze how professionals in different careers use computational thinking to solve real-world problems.
Describe how computing is used in a variety of industries and careers.
Examine how changes in technology can create new jobs or change how people work.
Discuss ways personal interests connect to computing in different industries and careers.
Investigate how professionals in computing careers address ethical dilemmas.
Explain how computing technologies and skills are used across different industries (e.g., healthcare, transportation, and entertainment).
Illustrate how technology-driven challenges require integrating computing knowledge and skills with expertise from diverse fields.
Examine how professionals across industries adopt new computing technologies and develop new expertise throughout their careers.
Investigate how professionals collaborate with computing technologies to solve problems creatively, accurately, and efficiently.
